SEARCH
Package sprouts

Class Problem

java.lang.Object
sprouts.Problem
public final class Problem extends Object
A problem is a wrapper for information describing an issue that can be reported and attached to a Result. It is used to describe what went wrong in a process. Like, for example, the process of getting a value, which is why it is also part of a Result that does not contain a value (null).
The Problem exposes various properties that describe what went wrong, such as a title, a description, an optional reporter object and an optional Exception that was thrown while getting the value.

This type has been designed to complement Java exceptions. Exceptions are great for us developers because they halt the current execution and give us a stack trace we can debug, but they do not always fail as gracefully as a user might expect. In a complex system where lots of things can go wrong, you want to catch exceptions and then collect them in a list of problems like so: 

      thingsThatWentWrong.add(Problem.of(myException));
This way your application continues to run and collect all the relevant problems that occurred so that they can then either be logged or presented to the user in a more graceful way.
The Result relies on this Problem type, instead of exceptions, because not every runtime issue is necessarily produced by an exception. If you do not want to disturb the control flow of your application by throwing an exception, you can create a Problem as part of a Result and continue processing.

  • Method Details

    • of

      public static Problem of(Exception e)
      A factory method for creating a problem from an Exception. The title of the problem will be the name of the exception class, the description will be the message of the exception (or cause if there is no message). The exception will be stored in the problem and can be retrieved with exception().
      Parameters:
      e - The exception to create a problem from.
      Returns:
      A problem that describes the given exception.

    • of

      public static Problem of(String title)
      A factory method for creating a problem with a title (and no description).
      Parameters:
      title - The title of the problem, which may not be null.
      Returns:
      A problem with the given title and description.

    • of

      public static Problem of(String title, String description)
      A factory method for creating a problem with a title and a description.
      Parameters:
      title - The title of the problem, which may not be null.
      description - The description of the problem, which may not be null.
      Returns:
      A problem with the given title and description.

    • of

      public static Problem of(Object reporter, String title, String description)
      A factory method for creating a problem with a title, a description and a reporter.
      Parameters:
      reporter - The reporter of the problem, which may not be null.
      title - The title of the problem, which may not be null.
      description - The description of the problem, which may not be null.
      Returns:
      A problem with the given title and description.

    • title

      public String title()
      Every problem has a title, which serves as a short, descriptive identifier. If a problem object is created from an exception, the title will be the name of the exception class.
      Returns:
      The title of the problem, which may not be null (but may be empty).

    • description

      public String description()
      A problem may have a description, which provides more detailed information about what went wrong. If a problem object is created from an exception, the description will be the message of the exception (or cause if there is no message).
      Returns:
      The description of the problem, which may not be null (but may be empty).

    • exception

      public Optional<Exception> exception()
      A problem object may or may not have an exception attached to it. It is assumed that this exception is the cause of the problem.
      Returns:
      The exception that was thrown while getting the value, if any.

    • reporter

      public Optional<Object> reporter()
      A problem object may or may not have a reporter attached to it. It is expected to be the object where the problem originated from.
      Returns:
      The object that reported the problem, if any.

    • printTo

      public void printTo(Writer out)
      Prints the title and description and optionally the exception to the given writer. If an exception is present, it will be printed with its stack trace. The writer will be flushed after the print operation.
      Parameters:
      out - The writer to print to, which may not be null.

    • printTo

      public void printTo(PrintWriter writer)
      Prints the title and description and optionally the exception to the given writer. If an exception is present, it will be printed with its stack trace. The writer will be flushed after the print operation.
      Parameters:
      writer - The writer to print to, which may not be null.

    • printToSystemOut

      public void printToSystemOut()
      Prints the title and description and optionally the exception to the standard output stream. If an exception is present, it will be printed with its stack trace.

    • logTo

      public void logTo(BiConsumer<String,Throwable> logger)
      Allows you to log the problem to a custom logger of your choice, by supplying a BiConsumer which takes a string message as the first argument and a Throwable as the second argument. The title and description will be logged as the message and the exception will be logged as the throwable. If there is no exception, a new throwable will be created to ensure that the log contains information about the invocation site of this method (which is important for debugging).

      A typical usage of this may look like this: 
      
      private static final Logger log = LoggerFactory.getLogger(MyClass.class);
      
      // ...
      
      problem.logTo(log::error);
      Parameters:
      logger - The logger to log to, which may not be null.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - If the logger is null.

    • logAsError

      public void logAsError()
      Logs the problem as a Logger.error(java.lang.String) message to the default logger of the implementing class. If a SLF4J backend is not available, it will log to the standard error stream System.err.

    • logAsWarning

      public void logAsWarning()
      Logs the problem as a Logger.warn(java.lang.String) message to the default logger of the implementing class. If a SLF4J backend is not available, it will log to the standard error stream System.err.

    • logAsInfo

      public void logAsInfo()
      Logs the problem as a Logger.info(java.lang.String) message to the default logger of the implementing class. If a SLF4J backend is not available, it will log to the standard output stream System.out.

    • logAsDebug

      public void logAsDebug()
      Logs the problem as a Logger.debug(java.lang.String) message to the default logger of the implementing class. If a SLF4J backend is not available, it will log to the standard output stream System.out.

    • logAsTrace

      public void logAsTrace()
      Logs the problem as a Logger.trace(java.lang.String) message to the default logger of the implementing class. If a SLF4J backend is not available, it will log to the standard output stream System.out.
